newsitem.title: USA: TENNIS-CAPRIATI ADVANCES IN OKLAHOMA CITY.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-CAPRIATI ADVANCES IN OKLAHOMA CITY.

text.p: Jennifer Capriati, playing her first match since leaving the Australian Open in tears last month, had a happier time at the IGA Tennis Classic on Tuesday.
The fifth-seeded Capriati shook off a slow start to beat Maria Alejandra Vento of Venezuela 6-3 6-4 in the first round.
Third seed Kimberly Po, who was just named to the U.S. Fed Cup team, and seventh seed Marianne Werdel Witmeyer also reached the second round.
The 19th-ranked Po held off compatriot Tami Whitlinger Jones 7-6 6-4, while Witmeyer caught a break when Nana Miyagi of Japan was forced to retire while on the verge of winning.
Miyagi won the first set 6-4 and was leading 5-3 in the second when she had to quit with a lower back sprain.
There was one minor upset when eighth-seeded Canadian Patricia Hy-Boulais fell to semi-retired veteran Pam Shriver 7-5 6-7 6-3.
The 20-year-old Capriati, in the second year of her comeback after her highly-publicised bouts with legal and personal problems, quickly fell behind 0-3 to Vento.
The former teen phenom then went on a tear, winning 11 of the next 12 games to take the first set 6-3 and a commanding 5-1 lead in the second.

"I kicked it in and played my game. I am happy with the way I am playing," said Capriati, who reached the final of the Sydney International only to suffer a devastating first-round loss at the year's first Grand Slam tournament days later.
Capriati shrugged off her shaky start against Vento.
"I guess I was a little nervous, had a little jitters," she explained. "This is the first time I have been seeded in awhile.
"I enjoy giving a good performance and I think the crowd just wants to see me do well."
